metadata.title: Depression  Occupational Therapy (Older Adults)
synonyms: unipolar mood disorder: occupational therapy (older adults)
mood disorder, unipolar: occupational therapy (older adults)
anatomical location body part affected: Symptoms are emotional, psychological, cognitive, and physical; the entire individual is affected by depression
description: Depression is a common psychological condition, affecting up to 30% of primary care patients.(1) Depression is even more common among older adults (age 65+); however, it can be difficult to accurately diagnose in this population due to medical comorbidities.(2) Depression is a primary mood disorder.(1,2,3) The diagnosis of depression is made when symptoms (e.g., depressed mood, decreased pleasure in activities) are present every day for a 2-week  period and constitute a change from prior level of functioning.(2,4,19) One key feature of mood disorders is that the patient cannot control the severity of his or her feelings.(3) Depression in older adults can result in decreased independence and quality of life, functional decline and disability, and a worsening of overall health and/or chronic medical conditions(5,13)

According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders , 5th edition ( DSM -5), depressive disorders include disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, major depressive disorder, dysthymia, premenstrual dysphoric disorder, substance/medication-induced depressive disorder, depressive disorder due to another medical condition, and unspecified depressive disorder(16)

There are four major types of depression, with overlapping symptoms in each group(1) 1.Adjustment disorder with depressed mood -Depression occurring in reaction to an identifiable stressor or difficult life situation -Onset is within 3 months of the incident; the depression causes significant impairment of social and/or occupational functioning 2.Depressive disorders -Major depressive disorder (MDD)(1) -Involves at least one episode of serious mood depression that occurs at any time of life(1) -Symptoms will vary significantly between patients; however, common complaints include loss of interest and/or pleasure in previously enjoyable activities (anhedonia), withdrawal from activities, and feelings of guilt (1,2) -Subcategories include major depression with atypical features; major depression with seasonal onset (seasonal affective disorder [SAD]); and major depression with postpartum onset (usually occurs within 2 weeks to 6 months postpartum)(1)  -Dysthymia(1) -Chronic depressive disturbance -Symptoms include sadness, loss of interest in previously enjoyable activities, and withdrawal from activities over a period of 2 or more years with a relatively persistent course -Symptoms are milder but longer-lasting  than in MDD -Premenstrual dysphoric disorder(1) -Depressive symptoms occur during the late luteal phase (last 2 weeks) of the patient’s menstrual cycle 3.Bipolar disorder(1) -Depressive disorder that consists of episodic mood shifts between mania, major depression, hypomania, and mixed mood states -High substance-abuse  comorbidity -Mania(1) -Mania is characterized by an episode of mood state involving elation with hyperactivity, overinvolvement in activities, increased irritability, flight of ideas, easy distractibility, and minimal sleep -Spring and summer are the peak periods for mania -Manic episodes are shorter than depressive episodes -The patient with bipolar disorder often has difficulty maintaining relationships due to the volatility of his or her mood -Patients with four or more discrete episodes of mood disturbance in 1 year are referred to as “rapid cyclers” -Cyclothymic disorders(1) -Chronic mood disturbances with episodes of depression and hypomania -Symptoms last at least 2 years and are milder than those occurring in depressive and manic episodes of bipolar disorder -Symptoms may escalate to the full manic and depressive episodes in bipolar disorder 4.Mood disorders secondary to illness and drugs(1) -Any type of illness, ranging from mild to severe, can cause significant depression -Drug-induced  depression has been documented with use of antihypertensive medications, corticosteroids, and oral contraceptives, as well as alcohol, sedatives, opiates, and psychedelic drugs

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The following symptoms can be present in patients with depression
Anorexia with unintentional weight loss (1,2,4) –Some patients with depression have significant weight gain, although this is not as common (2,3)

Cognitive dysfunction; especially impairment of thought processing, including inability to concentrate, ruminations, and lack of decisiveness (1,2) –Cognitive symptoms of depression in older adults are sometimes dismissed by physicians and caregivers as normal signs of aging(6)
Loss of interest in previously enjoyable activities, marked by a lack of involvement in work and recreational activities (1,2)
Mood ranges from mild unhappiness to extreme feelings of guilt, worthlessness, and hopelessness(1,2,3,4)

Physical symptoms such as headaches; disrupted, diminished, or excessive sleep; loss of energy and/or chronic fatigue; change in appetite; decreased sex drive; constipation(1,4) –For older adults, the physical symptoms of depression might not initially be attributed to depression as many of these symptoms also occur as a result of chronic illnesses(6)

Severe depression can result in the following symptoms: –Delusions of a hypochondriacal or persecutory nature(1,3) –Psychomotor retardation or agitation(1) –Severe agitation with psychotic ideation(1) –Somatic symptoms with major severity(1) –Recurrent thoughts of death and/or suicide(1,2,3,4) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: It is important that the occupational therapist (OT) develop a trusting and respectful relationship with the patient to help increase the patient’s motivation for therapy; when listening to the patient discuss his or her medical history as well as his or her thoughts and beliefs about depression, the OT must not dismiss the patient’s feelings because of the underlying depression(4,5,6,22,23,24,25)

pathogenesis: Depression results from changes in the receptor-neurotransmitter relationship in the limbic system(2)–Serotonin and norepinephrine are the primary neurotransmitters involved in depression; dopamine, acetylcholine, andγ-aminobutyric  acid (GABA) have also been documented to be involved in depression(2)–As an action potential is passed on, the neurotransmitter is either:(2)-Reabsorbed into the neuron, where it is either destroyed by an enzyme or its activity is removed by a reuptake pump andstored until needed OR-Destroyed by monoamine oxidase (MAO) in the mitochondria–Symptoms are related to decreased levels of norepinephrine (dullness and lethargy) and serotonin (irritability, hostility,and suicidal ideation)(2)
Depression may be related to abnormal responses to cortisol; elevated levels of cortisol are associated with depression(2)
risk factors: Advanced age (increased risk starting at age 65; risk further increases at age 85)(2,5,7)
Victim of domestic abuse or violence(2)

Living situation:–Almost 40% of acutely hospitalized older adults have some degree of depressive symptoms(26)–Older adults who live in high-poverty,  urban neighborhoods are at an increased risk for depression(27)

Presence of chronic illness(s)(2,7)–In the older adult population, the highest rates of depression are among patients with the following conditions: stroke,coronary artery disease, cancer, Parkinson disease, and Alzheimer disease(2,24)-For information on assessment and treatment of patients following stroke, see the series of Clinical Reviews on thistopic-For information on assessment and treatment of patients with Parkinson disease, see the series of Clinical Reviews onthis topic-For information on assessment and treatment of patients with Alzheimer disease, see  Clinical Review…Alzheimer’ sDisease: Occupational Therapy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708925
Strong family history of psychological conditions (including depression, bipolar disorder, suicide, alcoholism, othersubstance abuse)(2,7)
Stress (especially chronic stress) and/or recent loss(es)(2,3,4,14)

overall contraindications precautions: Screen older adult patients for signs of abuse and/or neglect; report to adult protective services if abuse is reported or suspected

The most significant complication in patients with depression is suicide; all verbal expressions of suicidal threat or intent should be taken seriously (1,3) Risk of suicide in the older adult population is 5.5 times greater than in the general population(5) –A group at especially high risk for suicide is patients with severe depression or psychotic illness with comorbid medical illness(1) –Routine screening for suicidal thoughts in older adults with depression (or suspected depression) is appropriate due to the significant risk of suicide(1,2,3,4,5,6) Although anxiety, panic, and fear are commonly associated with suicidal behavior, a patient may seem to make dramatic improvements immediately prior to a suicide attempt because the decision to commit suicide has lifted his or her depression(1) Risk factors for suicide in older adults with depression include use of alcohol, hopelessness, delusional thoughts, complete (or nearly complete) loss of interest in activities, previous suicide attempts, family history of suicide, medical illness, male sex, older age, contemplation of violent methods and/or access to firearms, history of childhood abuse, unemployment, panic attacks, a humiliating social stressor, and substance abuse(1,3)  If a patient presents with risk factors for suicide or describes suicidal thoughts, immediately contact the patient’s psychiatric professional (psychologist or psychiatrist) for evaluation(1) The demographic group with the highest suicide rate is older, single men(6,21)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Review medical history, including date of initial diagnosis, presenting symptoms, psychological and/or neuropsychological tests and reports, drug regimen, and medical, behavioral, and social management of depression to date

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management of depression will vary significantly from patient to patient(1) Patients with depression often present with physical complaints such as headache or chronic fatigue followed by a negative medical workup prior to the diagnosis of depression(1) Drug therapy for depression might not be indicated for patients with mild symptoms or for patients with depression associated with adjustment disorder(1) Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) causes a generalized CNS seizure(1,3) Often used in cases of refractory depression and in patients for whom antidepressant drugs are contraindicated(1,7) Can be effective for all types of depression and is very effective for severe depression and for resolving a manic episode(1) Memory loss is a common side effect of ECT(1,3) Phototherapy(1) Used for patients with major depression with seasonal onset (SAD)(1) Involves exposure to a light source of 2,050 lux for 2 hours daily(1) Patients with very severe or intractable depression might opt for experimental treatments that are in investigational stages, including transcranial magnetic stimulation and vagal nerve stimulation(1) Authors of an overview of systematic reviews that evaluated 367 RCTs, involving approximately 20,000 patients, that evaluated treatments for depression found that nonpharmacologic treatment for depression (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy, physical activity interventions) reduced depression severity and may be appropriate for use, along with antidepressant therapy, in the management of depression(23)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Pharmacotherapy is often recommended for patients with significant symptoms of depression and for patients in whom symptoms have lasted more than a few weeks(1) Also indicated for patients with a personal history of major depression or a family history of major depression in a firstdegree relative(1) It is not uncommon for a patient’s physician to switch drugs several times throughout treatment for depression prior to finding a drug or combination of drugs that successfully manages the patient’s symptoms(3) Older adults often need to start with smaller dosages of antidepressants, as they frequently are more sensitive to medication than are younger patients; this means older adults can require medication for longer periods(2,14,23) Medications prescribed for depression often have side effects; note the possible side effects when reviewing the patient’s current medication list(2,7)  SSRIs (e.g., sertraline, fluoxetine)(1,2) Bupropion(1,2) Selective serotonin-norepinephrine  reuptake inhibitors (SSNRIs) (e.g., fluoxetine, sertraline, paroxetine) (1,2) Mirtazapine(1) Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)(1,2) Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs)(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed : Diagnostic tests completed for patients with depression are usually intended to rule out other diagnoses as the underlying cause of symptoms(2)
Diagnostic tests often include blood work, thyroid panel, ECG, etc.(2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help St. John’s wort is an herbal supplement commonly taken for depression; however, randomized clinical trials have shown minimal to no benefit of St. John’s wort when compared to placebo(3) Long-term  studies of St. John’s wort have found that it has a profound effect on the liver and impacts the way in which other drugs are metabolized(3) Ecotherapy, animal therapy, and water therapy have been utilized in research studies for treatment of depression(3)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had psychotherapy or occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Are there certain situations in which the patient has more difficulty or an exacerbation of symptoms? -Are there activities that seem to alleviate or lessen symptoms?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of both physical symptoms, if present (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) and/or cognitive/emotional symptoms
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much ) and location of any physical symptoms
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also, document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Sleep disturbance -Insomnia, hypersomnia, and other sleep disturbances are common in patients with depression(1,2,3,14,25) -Document number of awakenings/night, if occurring -Document sleep aids and frequency of use -Document amount of sleep the patient gets each night -Does the patient sleep during the day? If so, how many hours?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient become short of breath? If so, when? Standing? Walking? With exercise? Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of depression or other mental illness?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Depression often co-occurs  with a serious medical illness. (1,4) Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, other psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders(2) Schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorders  Bipolar disorder Grief reaction Anxiety disorders Somatoform disorders Substance abuse Medical comorbidities There is an increased risk of cardiovascular disease in women with depression(1,2,3,7,14)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs and supplements)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What are the patient’s occupations and role(s) within his or her family?(4,18,20,22) -For older adults, the lack of occupations, due to retirement, injury, illness, loss of loved ones, etc., can be a significant factor in depression; the results of some studies even suggest this loss of occupation is the main cause of depression in older adults(4,18,22,24) -What activities, hobbies, etc., did the patient enjoy prior to the onset of depression?(25) -It is important to determine which activities are or were important to the patient in order to motivate the patient to participate in therapy(4,20,22,25,27) -A patient/caregiver interview may be helpful to gain insight into the patient’s hobbies, family/community roles, interests, work status, and home responsibilities
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What current assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it still be utilized based on patient’s current level of functioning? -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -The living environment of an older adult can significantly impair his or her ability to socialize and/or participate in activities of leisure; the environment can also have a significant impact on one’s occupation(s)(20,21,22,27) -Does the patient have supportive family members? Do those family members live near and/or have the ability to provide assistance?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Note BMI –Patients with depression can have changes in appetite, resulting in either significant weight gain or loss (i.e., weight loss without dieting)(2)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or current use of assistive and adaptive devices;(5,13) incorrect use of devices can increase risk of falls –Mobility aids -Cane -Walker -Wheelchair -Crutches  -Hemi-walker -Ankle-foot  orthoses (AFOs) –Toileting and showering equipment -Grab bars -Bedside commode -A urinal at bedside -Raised toilet seat -Shower chair/tub bench -Elevated foot rest at the toilet –ADL/IADL aids -Reachers -Personal digital assistant (PDA) -Large-print  reading material -Adaptive/ergonomic computer/mouse/keyboard -Text-to-speech  software -Adaptive cooking equipment
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance functionally during ADL tasks –Tinetti Balance Scale –Berg Balance Scale –Functional Reach Test
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesBed mobility and transfers should be assessed to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity –Test static and dynamic activitiesa measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, which are all important for independent mobility(8) –FIM – an 18-item,  7-level  ordinal scale assessing functional mobility, ADLs, language skills, and cognition(9)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted) –Note use of braces or ambulatory aids for walking –If the patient presents with impaired gait, referral to physical therapy may be appropriateAssess fine and gross motor function of the upper extremities; describe the quality of movement
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers; do not perform MMT with contracted muscles or muscles with tone and coordination issues –Dynamometer to evaluate hand strength bilaterally –Assess grip force in functional tasks –Assess pinch strength
observation inspection palpation includi: Ocular motor screening includes tracking through all planes, visual accommodation, and clarity of vision
Document complaints of double vision, optic pain, or visual field cuts
Referral to ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology  is appropriate if symptoms of visual disturbances are noted during
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Patients with depression can have cognitive dysfunction, especially impairment of thought processing, including inability to concentrate, ruminations, and lack of decisiveness (1,2) –Cognitive dysfunction in patients with depression can impair the ability to complete tasks for work and/or pleasure(11) –A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) is appropriate for patients with depression (6) –For patients with significant cognitive impairment, referral to neuropsychology is appropriate for extensive assessment and input regarding cognitive intervention

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The OT will determine the need for intervention after a comprehensive evaluation; the OT must consider each patient’s risk factors and deficits to determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for therapy. Older adults with depression might be apathetic or lack motivation to participate in therapy; this can have a negative impact on overall rehabilitation.(11,18,20,23,25) It may be necessary to address the symptoms of depression prior to treating other needs in order for the patient o receive maximal benefit from therapy in general(25)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out or diagnose other diseases and psychological disorders prior to making a diagnosis of depression. The differential diagnosis for depression includes:  Adrenal disease(2,7) Anxiety disorders(7) Cancer(2,15) Chronic fatigue syndrome(2,15) Dementia(7,24) –Patient may present with memory problems and treatment of depression reverses the deficits(2) –High prevalence of depressive symptoms and major depressive disorder, particularly with vascular dementia(24) Eating disorders(7) Endocrine and thyroid dysfunction and disorders(2,7) Liver/renal failure(2) Lupus(2) Medications (abuse, side effects, overdose)(2,7) Metabolic abnormalities(2) Nutritional deficiencies (vitamin B12 deficiency, pernicious anemia, pellagra)(2,7) Parkinson disease Thyroid disorders Organic brain diseases(2) Heart disease Stroke Psychotic disorders(7) Substance abuse, dependence, and/or withdrawal(2,7)
prognosis: In patients with a single depressive episode, 50% will develop a recurrent episode(2) –Management of depression is long-term  and multifaceted(2)
Reactive depressions are generally time-limited  and prognosis is good(1)
Major affective disorders frequently respond well with appropriate drug therapy(1)
Older adult patients may have with worse outcomes than younger patients due to physical comorbidities and other factors(14)
Bipolar disorder has a good prognosis with appropriate treatment(1)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referral to physical therapy if the patient has difficulty with gait, ambulation, balance, transfers, or weight-bearing Referral to recreational or vocational therapist for returning to activities of leisure and employment Referral to psychiatry, psychology, or social work if patient with depression is not currently under the care of a mental health professional and/or may benefit from assistance with issues such as facility placement Adult protective services for home services/equipment or if abusive situation is suspected Referral to physician for reevaluation of effectiveness of drug therapy and exploration of other treatment options such as deep brain stimulation(17) Referral to art therapy and/or music therapy(19)
other considerations: Depression is a complicated disorder that is most effectively managed with a combination of medical, psychological, social, and behavioral treatments(1)

It is important that the OT develop a trusting and respectful relationship with the patient to help increase the patient’s motivation for therapy(18,19,20,25) –The OT can also promote social connections and support as well as encourage the patient to reengage in the activities he or she once enjoyed, as these connections are important components of recovery from depression(5)

Having a family member with depression can be extremely stressful for the patient’s loved ones, caregiver(s), spouse, etc.(4) –Consider the entire family/support network during evaluation and treatment of the patient with depression; refer for marriage and family therapy and counseling if appropriate(4) –Family-focused  or dyadic interventions may have a greater effect size for improving symptoms and function for patients with depression compared to intervention focused solely on the patient(22) -These findings are based on a systematic review conducted in the United States. The authors of the review identified 13 papers from 10 investigations that focused on including spouses or close family members/support persons in the treatment of patients with major depression. They found that dyadic interventions are feasible and that they may have a larger treatment effect than “single-target” approaches to treatment
treatment summary: Therapy might focus on improving medication/time management, ADLs/IADLs, community mobility and/or reentry, reestablishing daily routines, social integration, functional behavior training, and restoring motor and/or cognitive functioning(4) –Occupational therapy programs for patients with depression should be unique and tailored to the needs, goals, prior level of function, coping strategies, and motivational factors of the specific patient(4,6,11,18,20,25)
Occupational therapists treating patients with depression can help them manage leisure, work and social activities to have better balance in their lives(20)

Occupational therapy goals for patients with depression should be small and achievable, changing frequently to reflect the patient’s current needs and abilities; if the goals are too difficult to achieve in a reasonable amount of time, the patient may give up, feeling that his or her belief that he or she is incompetent or worthless is accurate(4,5,24,25)

In 2015, the United Kingdom’s National Institute for Health and Care Excellence published the following recommendations for occupational therapy interventions and physical activity as a means of promoting mental well-being for older adults in primary and residential care(10) –OTs should: -Offer regular group and/or individual treatment sessions to encourage older adults to identify, create, practice, and carry out ADLs and activities that help to maintain or improve their health and well-being -Involve the older adult as an expert and partner in goal setting for maintaining or improving quality of life -Focus on communication, physical access to the therapist, length of sessions, and informality in order to encourage the exchange of ideas and promote a supportive environment -Ensure that treatment sessions take place in an environment and style that best meet the needs of the specific patient or group -Provide practical solutions for the areas in which the patient feels he or she has difficulty -Increase the patient’s knowledge and awareness of where to get reliable information and advice on a broad range of topics by providing information directly, inviting speakers to give informal talks, or arranging trips and social activities -Topics should include: -Meeting or maintaining healthcare needs (e.g., eye health, hearing problems, foot care) -Nutrition (e.g., simple, healthy meal preparation) -Personal care -Remaining physically active and increasing daily mobility -Accessing public services and government benefits -Home and community safety -Using public transportation -Invite regular feedback from the patient (or patients for group therapy) and utilize it to improve future sessions and to gauge levels of motivation
Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)(4) –An OT can be trained and qualified to use CBT to aid in the rehabilitation of patients with depression(4)

ADLs/IADLs(4,25) –Developing plans and routines to successfully complete ADLs/IADLs is important for patients with depression in order for them to feel empowered, motivated, and independent(4,5,18,20,23,24,25) -An important role for the OT is developing routines for medication management along with the patient and reinforcing the need to take antidepressant medications as prescribed by the physician; remind the patient that initially the medicines can take up to 3–4 weeks to take full effect(23) –Allow increased time for patients to complete ADLs/IADLs; provide patient and caregiver education regarding extended time to complete self-care  routines where appropriate –ADL/IADL training in older adult patients with depression should include leisure activities(11) -A review of the literature including studies of the effects of leisure activities on depression in older adults found that leisure activities were associated with increased levels of self-esteem  and decreased levels of depression(11) –Authors of a 2014 study evaluating how patients adapt ADLs in later-life  depression found four themes that negatively influenced function(18) -Participants in the study reported they no longer continued activities when they -were no longer meaningful -when the activity required more physical or cognitive energy than participants had or chose to expend -when the activity was too physically painful to do -when the activity exceeded personal space boundaries –If needed, the OT can help the patient select assistive devices and then train the patient to use them to increase independence in ADLs/IADLs

Exercise(10,12) –Authors of a systematic review of the evidence that included only randomized trials found that exercise is an effective method for alleviation of the symptoms of depression(12) -A significant effect was found for moderate-intensity exerciseprograms with a mix of aerobic and strengthening activities(12) -Group exercise programs were effective in reducing depressive symptoms in older adults, while non-group sessions were less effective(12) –In a 2018 randomized trial study of 114 nursing home residents, investigators found that greater levels of strength and physical activity were positively associated with improved performance on depression scales and quality of life outcomes in older adults with mild to moderate cognitive impairments(12)

Group therapy/support group(5) –Groups serve to educate patients about coping skills and how they can be used to manage the symptoms of depression –Group therapy settings can also provide consultation, health promotion, restoration and remediation, prevention of further disability through psychoeducation, social skills training, referral to appropriate disciplines or resources, and case management –The group setting can empower patients to manage their depression rather than allowing depression to control their lives

Life-review  writing treatment –The authors of an RCT involving older adults in the United States found significant improvements in depressive symptoms with a life review through writing intervention(15) -Forty-five  participants (23 treatment group versus 22 wait-list  control group) -The treatment group participated in a weekly 90-minute  intervention for 8 weeks that included presentation on writing techniques and encouragement to write stories about experiences and life outside of the workshop -Each session, patients were asked to read their written work aloud and afterwards received positive feedback from other group members and the group leader -The waitlist control group also participated in the same 8-week  writing workshop after testing was completed . maintenance or prevention: Maintenance of occupational and cognitive functioning in older adults with depression involves long-term  management and follow-up,  which may include lifestyle changes(2) Prevention of suicide in this patient population requires that all professionals be aware of suicide risk factors and that all verbal expressions of suicidal threat or intent be taken seriously (1,3)
patient education: Educating patients and their families/caregivers is an important part of occupational therapy for depression; patients are more likely to adhere to recommendations when they understand the rationale for treatment protocols(4,18,20,22,23,24,25)
